payload.name: sensemaking-frame-building
payload.core: Determine 'what kind of situation is this?' by building frames that organize signals, priorities, and actions under ambiguity. Precedes most other modes by selecting what counts as relevant evidence and what questions to ask. A frame is not a hypothesis about causeâ€”it is a lens that determines which hypotheses are even worth considering.

out.d: named pattern characterizing the situation type (e.g., 'competitive threat', 'execution breakdown', 'market shift')
out.test: frame has a name, 1-sentence definition, and explicit scope boundaries

out.d: 2-4 alternative frames considered before selection with fit rationale for each
out.test: each candidate has: name, what it explains, what it ignores

out.d: 3-5 key assumptions the selected frame requires to hold
out.test: each assumption is falsifiable and linked to a revision trigger

out.d: criteria for what signals matter under this frame vs noise
out.test: can classify new observation as relevant/irrelevant with explicit rationale

out.d: what questions to ask, data to gather, and stakeholders to involve given this frame
out.test: >=3 concrete next steps that follow logically from frame

out.d: specific observable signals that would force reframing
out.test: each trigger names: signal, threshold, and which alternative frame it suggests

proc: SIGNAL INVENTORY: list anomalies, constraints, stakeholder concerns, and available data without interpretation; flag signals that don't fit existing mental models; note what is confusing, not just what is clear

FRAME GENERATION: name 2-4 candidate situation types this could be; include (a) most obvious frame, (b) frame that explains the most puzzling signal, (c) frame stakeholders would resist; each frame needs a name and 1-sentence characterization

FIT TESTING: for each candidate frame, explicitly list (1) signals it explains well, (2) signals it ignores or struggles with, (3) what actions it would suggest; score each frame 1-3 on explanatory coverage
FRAME SELECTION: choose best-fit frame; if top two frames are within 1 point, either (a) gather discriminating signal, or (b) hold both frames provisionally and note which actions differ
ASSUMPTION SURFACING: for selected frame, state 3-5 key assumptions it requires; for each assumption, define what observable evidence would falsify it

IMPLICATION DERIVATION: derive concrete next actions, questions to pursue, and evidence to gather that follow from this frame; if actions are identical across multiple frames, frame selection may not matter yet

TRIGGER SETTING: define specific signals (with thresholds where possible) that would force frame revision; schedule explicit frame-check moments (e.g., 'reassess frame after first stakeholder meeting')
check: >=2 candidate frames articulated before any frame selected
selected frame explicitly named with 1-sentence characterization
>=3 frame assumptions documented with falsification criteria
relevance filter stated: what signals matter vs noise under this frame
>=3 concrete actions derived that follow from frame (not generic 'gather more data')
revision triggers defined with specific signals and thresholds
stakeholders can articulate frame in their own words (shared mental model test)
frame is a situation type, not a causal hypothesis (if it's a hypothesis, use abductive)
quick_check: Can I name my current frame in 3 words or fewer?
Did I consider at least one frame stakeholders would resist?
Can I state what evidence would make me reframe?
Are my next actions specific to this frame, or would they be the same under any frame?
If I'm explaining why something happened, am I doing sensemaking or abductive? (Sensemaking = situation type; abductive = causal explanation)

abductive.contrast: abductive generates hypotheses about specific causes; sensemaking selects which problem space to hypothesize within
abductive.boundary: frame = 'this is a competitive threat situation'; hypothesis = 'competitor X launched product Y causing our decline'
abductive.test: if you're asking 'why did X happen?', use abductive. If you're asking 'what kind of situation is this?', use sensemaking

hermeneutic.contrast: hermeneutic interprets meaning of existing signals; sensemaking decides which signals to attend to
hermeneutic.boundary: hermeneutic asks 'what does this memo mean?'; sensemaking asks 'is this memo even relevant to our situation?'
hermeneutic.test: if you have a specific text/asset to interpret, use hermeneutic. If you're deciding what to focus on, use sensemaking

meta-reasoning.contrast: meta-reasoning selects reasoning mode; sensemaking establishes what problem is before mode selection
meta-reasoning.boundary: sensemaking: 'this is a crisis, not a routine issue'; meta-reasoning: 'for crises, use satisficing + heuristic mode'
meta-reasoning.test: sensemaking answers 'what situation?'; meta-reasoning answers 'how to reason about it?'; sensemaking typically precedes meta-reasoning

diagnostic.contrast: diagnostic identifies root cause within an established frame; sensemaking chooses the frame that defines what counts as a cause
diagnostic.boundary: sensemaking: 'this is a people problem, not a technology problem'; diagnostic: 'which person/process failed?'
diagnostic.test: if fault taxonomy is known and you're localizing within it, use diagnostic. If you're unsure what taxonomy applies, use sensemaking

narrative.contrast: narrative builds coherent story from events; sensemaking builds interpretive frame that determines which events belong in the story
narrative.boundary: sensemaking: 'this is a story about market disruption'; narrative: 'here's the timeline of how the disruption unfolded'
narrative.test: if you're constructing a causal chain of events, use narrative. If you're deciding what kind of story this is, use sensemaking

systems-thinking.contrast: systems-thinking maps feedback loops and emergent behavior; sensemaking decides whether systems-level framing is even appropriate
systems-thinking.boundary: sensemaking: 'this is a systemic issue, not a one-time failure'; systems-thinking: 'here are the reinforcing loops causing it'
systems-thinking.test: if you're mapping loops and delays, use systems-thinking. If you're deciding whether to zoom out to system level, use sensemaking

confusions.trap: using sensemaking when abductive is needed
confusions.symptom: frame keeps shifting because you're actually trying to explain a specific anomaly, not characterize a situation type
confusions.correction: if your 'frame' is really a causal hypothesis (e.g., 'competitor sabotage'), switch to abductive. Frames are situation types (e.g., 'competitive threat'), not explanations

confusions.trap: skipping sensemaking and jumping to diagnostic
confusions.symptom: elegant root cause analysis that solves the wrong problem; stakeholders say 'that's not what this is about'
confusions.correction: before diagnostic, confirm frame alignment with stakeholders. If stakeholders have different implicit frames, sensemaking first

confusions.symptom: defending frame against disconfirming evidence; 'I already decided this is a technology problem'
confusions.correction: frames are provisional working hypotheses about situation type. Schedule explicit reframe checkpoints; frames should be held lightly

confusions.symptom: generating many frames without fit-testing or selection criteria; analysis paralysis
confusions.correction: limit to 2-4 frames; score each on explanatory coverage; select and commit (provisionally) rather than holding all possibilities

fail.name: premature frame lock-in
fail.desc: Adopting first plausible frame without considering alternatives; defending frame against disconfirming evidence; reasoning correctly within wrong frame
signals: first frame adopted without articulating alternatives
disconfirming evidence dismissed as noise or exception
perfect reasoning inside frame yielding answers stakeholders reject
stakeholders using incompatible implicit frames without awareness
frame assumptions never stated or tested
no revision triggers defined; frame treated as fact

mitigations.test: frame_candidates.length >= 2 with fit rationale for each

mitigations.m: name current frame explicitly so it can be questioned
state frame assumptions with falsification criteria

mitigations.test: revision_triggers non-empty with specific signals and thresholds
explicit checkpoint scheduled (e.g., 'recheck frame after X')

mitigations.m: test frame with outsider or red team
mitigations.test: at least one person outside core team asked 'does this frame fit?'

mitigations.m: ask 'what would make us reframe?' before major decisions
mitigations.test: revision triggers reviewed before committing resources

mitigations.m: track frame-action coupling: if actions would be same under different frame, frame may not matter yet
mitigations.test: action_implications differ across top candidate frames

use: crisis leadership under novel conditions: 'is this a PR crisis, a safety crisis, or a legal crisis?'
early-stage strategy formulation: 'is this a growth problem, a competition problem, or a capability problem?'
ambiguous competitive landscapes: 'is this market converging, fragmenting, or being disrupted?'
novel situations lacking precedent: 'what historical situations is this most like?'
problem formulation before solution search: 'what kind of problem are we actually solving?'
cross-functional alignment: 'do engineering, product, and sales see this the same way?'
post-incident framing: 'was this a technology failure, a process failure, or a communication failure?'

rel.name: abductive
rel.role: generates candidate frames; use abductive within frame to generate causal hypotheses

rel.name: meta-reasoning
rel.role: selects reasoning approach after framing established

rel.name: diagnostic
rel.role: localizes fault within frame; sensemaking chooses which fault model applies

rel.name: narrative-causal-storytelling
rel.role: builds causal story within frame; sensemaking determines what kind of story

rel.name: systems-thinking
rel.role: maps system dynamics; sensemaking decides whether systemic framing appropriate

micro_ex.sit: Team velocity dropped 40% over two sprints; no obvious cause

frames_considered.name: technical debt crisis
frames_considered.explains: slowdown correlates with legacy module work

frames_considered.name: team dynamics breakdown
frames_considered.explains: recent tension in retros, key departure

micro_ex.revision_trigger: if 1:1s reveal technical blockers as primary complaint, reframe to technical debt

ex.situation: Sales suddenly down 30% in key region, no obvious cause
signal_inventory: revenue drop concentrated in enterprise segment
competitor mentioned in 3 lost deals (but also mentioned last quarter)
new regulation announced 6 weeks ago (uncertain impact)

frames_considered.name: competitor disruption
frames_considered.ignores: competitor was mentioned before without this impact

frames_considered.name: internal execution failure
frames_considered.ignores: no process changes, team is same

frames_considered.name: market shift / regulatory
frames_considered.explains: timing with regulation, buyer confusion, enterprise concentration

ex.selected_frame: market shift (new regulation changing buyer behavior)
key_assumptions: regulation impact is structural, not temporary
buyer confusion stems from compliance uncertainty, not our messaging
enterprise concentration is because regulation hits large buyers first

revision_triggers.signal: competitor analysis shows new product launch
sales team identifies internal process blocker
regulation guidance clarifies no material impact

action_implications: interview 5 enterprise buyers about compliance concerns
map regulation requirements to product capabilities
draft compliance positioning for sales team
pause sales process investigation (low priority under this frame)
ex.outcome: frame validated; buyers confirmed compliance uncertainty; pivoted product positioning to new requirements; sales recovered in 6 weeks
